nodes.content:
Introduction to Canonical Tags

Canonical tags are a useful tool for website owners to help search engines understand which version of a page should be considered the “main” or “preferred” version. Implementing canonical tags can help you avoid duplicated content issues and ensure that your website’s pages are properly indexed and ranked by search engines and you will get a proper setup Magento 2 website. In this blog, we will discuss how to add canonical tags in Magento 2.

Steps to Add Canonical Tags in Magento 2

Step 1: Install and configure Canonical URL extension:

To add canonical tags in Magento 2, you can use a third-party extension such as the Canonical URL extension. This extension provides a simple and efficient way to add canonical tags to your Magento 2 website. To install the Canonical URL extension, log in to your Magento 2 admin panel and navigate to the Magento Marketplace. Search for the Canonical URL extension, and follow the instructions to install and configure the extension.

Step 2: Set up Canonical URLs for your Magento 2 website:

Once the Canonical URL extension is installed and configured, you can start setting up canonical tags for your Magento 2 website. To do this, navigate to the “Stores” menu, select “Settings”, then “Configuration”, and select “Catalog” from the left-side menu. Under “Canonical URL”, select “Yes” to enable canonical tags for your Magento 2 website.

Step 3: Specify the Canonical URLs for your pages:

To specify the canonical URLs for your pages, navigate to the “Product” or “Category” sections of the Magento 2 admin panel, and select the page you want to add a canonical tag to. Scroll down to the “Search Engine Optimization” section, and enter the preferred URL for that page in the “Canonical URL” field.

Step 4: Verify the implementation of Canonical URLs:

Once you have completed the steps above, you can verify the implementation of your canonical tags by viewing the source code of your pages. To do this, right-click on any page on your website and select “View Source”. Look for the “rel=”canonical”” tag in the source code, and verify that the URL specified is the preferred URL for that page.

Conclusion:

Adding canonical tags in Magento 2 is a straightforward process that can help you avoid duplicated content issues and improve your website’s ranking and visibility in search engines. By using a third-party extension such as the Canonical URL extension and following the steps outlined in this blog, you can easily and efficiently add canonical tags to your Magento 2 website.

nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a highly flexible e-commerce platform that provides a wide range of customization options for website owners, including configurable products in Magento 2. One such customization option is the ability to hide or unhide product images on the product page. If you have accidentally hidden product images and want to make them visible … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a highly flexible e-commerce platform that provides a wide range of customization options for website owners, including configurable products in Magento 2. One such customization option is the ability to hide or unhide product images on the product page. If you have accidentally hidden product images and want to make them visible again, this guide will walk you through the process of how to Unhide all Product Images on Product Page in Magento 2.

Steps to Unhide All Product Images on Product Page in Magento 2

Step 1: Log into Magento 2 Admin Panel

The first step is to log into the Magento 2 admin panel using your username and password.

Step 2: Navigate to the Product Grid

Once logged in, go to the “Products” section in the Magento 2 admin panel and click on the “Catalog” tab. This will take you to the product grid, where you can see a list of all your products.

Step 3: Select the Product

From the product grid, select the product whose images you want to unhide. You can do this by clicking on the checkbox next to the product name.

Step 4: Edit the Product

Once the product is selected, click on the “Edit” button at the top of the screen. This will take you to the product edit page.

Step 5: Navigate to the Images Tab

On the product edit page, navigate to the “Images” tab. This is where you can manage the images for the product.

Step 6: Unhide the Images

In the images tab, you will see a list of all the images for the product. Find the image that you want to unhide and click on the “Exclude” button. This will unhide the image and make it visible on the product page.

Step 7: Save Changes

Once you have unhidden all the necessary images, click on the “Save” button at the top of the screen to save the changes.

And that’s it! These simple steps will help you unhide all the product images on your product page in Magento 2.

Note: If you want to unhide all images at once, you can select all the images by clicking on the checkbox in the header row, and then click on the “Exclude” button.

Conclusion

In conclusion, Magento 2 provides a simple and straightforward way to unhide product images on the product page. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can easily manage and display all the images for your products on your website. Whether you have accidentally hidden a single image or multiple images, this guide will help you unhide them and ensure that your customers can see all the necessary information and images for your products.

nodes.title: How To Make Order Status Visible on Frontend in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a powerful e-commerce platform that provides a lot of flexibility and customization options for store owners. One such customization is the ability to show the order status on the frontend for customers to see, as well as the ability to select an auto shipping method. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a powerful e-commerce platform that provides a lot of flexibility and customization options for store owners. One such customization is the ability to show the order status on the frontend for customers to see, as well as the ability to select an auto shipping method. By default, Magento 2 does not display the order status on the frontend, but this information can be easily made visible with a few simple steps. In this blog, we’ll show you how to make the order status visible on the frontend in Magento 2.

Steps to Make Order Status Visible on Frontend in Magento 2

Step 1: Log in to the Magento 2 backend

To get started, log in to the Magento 2 backend using your admin credentials. Once logged in, navigate to the Stores menu and then to the Configuration section.

Step 2: Navigate to the Sales section

Under the Configuration menu, look for the Sales section and click on it. In the Sales section, you will find several sub-sections including Orders, Invoices, Shipments, and Credit Memos.

Step 3: Navigate to the Orders section

Click on the Orders section and then look for the Order Options sub-section. In the Order Options section, you will find the “Display Orders and Newsletter Statuses” option. By default, this option is set to “No.”

Step 4: Change the option to “Yes”

To make the order status visible on the frontend, change the “Display Orders and Newsletter Statuses” option to “Yes.” Once you have made this change, click the “Save Config” button at the top of the page to save your changes.

Step 5: Verify the changes on the frontend

To verify that the order status is now visible on the frontend, log out of the backend and navigate to your store’s frontend. Look for the My Account section and then click on the Order History link. In the Order History section, you should now see the order status for each order.

Conclusion

In conclusion, making the order status visible on the frontend in Magento 2 is a simple process that can be accomplished in just a few steps. By following the steps outlined in this blog, you can provide your customers with easy access to their order status, which can improve their experience on your store and encourage repeat purchases.

nodes.title: How to Integrate a Live Chat to Magento 2?
nodes.excerpt: Every eStore owner knows the importance of Live Chat to their site, but perhaps using just words cannot describe how important it is to integrate Live Chat in M2. nodes.content:
Every eStore owner knows the importance of Live Chat to their site, but perhaps using just words cannot describe how important it is to integrate Live Chat in M2. It provides Real-time Customer Support, boosts sales, and generates customer behavior data for further study. Nowadays, there are plenty of Live Chat services for you to choose from. In this article, we will guide you through the process of how to integrate a live chat to Magento 2 sites.

Simple Guide: How To Integrate A Live Chat To Magento 2

Step 1: Establish a Module

In this step, we establish a module named “LiveChat”.

To set up the module, you must create a registration file located at: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/registration.php

Note: Webguru is the company name used in this example. You can use any name that suits your needs.

<?php

\Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::register(

    \Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::MODULE,

    'Webguru_LiveChat',

    __DIR__

);

Then create: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/etc/module.xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"

xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:Module/etc/module.xsd">

<module name="Webguru_LiveChat" setup_version="1.0.0">

</module>

</config>

Open your terminal, type:       

cd /var/www/html/magento2.1.6/

Please note that this guide uses M2 version 2.1.6, and the folder path may vary for different versions.

Then type: 

sudo bin/magento setup:upgrade

and  

sudo chmod -R 777 var pub

Go to your phpmyadmin, if there is “Webguru_LiveChat” in setup_module, your module is installed.

Step 2: Create a menu

Create: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/etc/adminhtml/menu.xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:module:Magento_Backend:etc/menu.xsd">

    <menu>

        <add id="Webguru_LiveChat::menu"

             title="Live Chat"

             module="Webguru_LiveChat"

             sortOrder="25"

             resource="Magento_Backend::system" />

        <add id="Webguru_LiveChat::memberMenu"

             title="Live Chat Setting"

             module="Webguru_LiveChat"

             sortOrder="10"

             parent="Webguru_LiveChat::menu"

             resource="Webguru_LiveChat::config_livechat" />

        <add id="Webguru_LiveChat::configuration"

             title="Configuration"

             module="Webguru_LiveChat"

             sortOrder="15"

             action="adminhtml/system_config/edit/section/Webguru_livechat/"

             parent="Webguru_LiveChat::memberMenu"

             resource="Webguru_LiveChat::config_livechat" />

    </menu>

</config>

In the terminal, type:    

sudo rm -rf var

To provide exceptional customer service, integrate live chat for Magento 2. Select compatible software, install the code, and configure settings to suit your business needs. For more information, As for How to Speed Up Magento 2. To improve website performance and conversion rates for M2, optimize with fast hosting, caching, and image optimization. Seek the help of a developer or refer to its official documentation. Also, consider integrating Magento 2 live chat for enhanced user experience.

Step 3: Configure the Settings

In the previous step, you successfully created a menu. Now, it’s time to set up the configuration.

action=”adminhtml/system_config/edit/section/Webguru_livechat/”

In order to go to the configuration, we need to set up the configuration for that link.

Create: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/etc/adminhtml/system.xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<config xmlns:xsi="//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"

        xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:module:Magento_Config:etc/system_file.xsd">

    <system>

        <tab id="Webguru" translate="label" sortOrder="200">

            <label>Webguru</label>

        </tab>

        <section id="Webguru_livechat" translate="label" type="text" sortOrder="80" showInDefault="1" showInWebsite="1" showInStore="1">

            <class>separator-top</class>

            <label>Live Chat</label>

            <tab>Webguru</tab>

            <resource>Webguru_LiveChat::config_livechat</resource>

            <group id="livechat" translate="label" type="select" sortOrder="30" showInDefault="1" showInWebsite="1"

                   showInStore="1">

                <label>Live Chat</label>

                <field id="enabled" translate="label comment" type="select" sortOrder="10" showInDefault="1"

                       showInWebsite="1" showInStore="1">

                    <label>Enable</label>

                    <source_model>Magento\Config\Model\Config\Source\Yesno</source_model>

                </field>

                <field id="widget" translate="label" type="text" sortOrder="20" showInDefault="1" showInWebsite="0"

                       showInStore="0">

                    <label>Widget</label>

                    <validate>required-entry</validate>

                    <depends>

                        <field id="enabled">1</field>

                    </depends>

                </field>

            </group>

        </section>

    </system>

</config>

In the terminal, type:  

sudo rm -rf var

From the live chat menu, click LIVE CHAT > Configuration

The configuration section has been successfully set up.

Step 4: Obtain the Widget Code from a Live Chat Service

In this tutorial, we use Chat Pirate as an example, but the process should be similar to other live conversation services.

1. Sign up for an account on chatpirate.com and access the dashboard.

2. Navigate to Settings > Integrations > Website

3. Copy the code and paste it into the Widget field in the Live Chat configuration.

4. Click “Save Config” and refresh the cache through Cache Management by selecting all and clicking “Submit refresh.”

If you have the widget code, integrating a chat to M2 is easy. Learn how to integrate a live chat to Magento 2 with our comprehensive guide. Then, complete the final step to enhance customer support and satisfaction.

Step 5: Implement on the Front-End

Retrieve the Widget Code from the Configuration established in the previous step.

Create: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/Block/Adminhtml/LiveChatHelper/LiveChatConfig.php

<?php

namespace Webguru\LiveChat\Block\Adminhtml\LiveChatHelper;

class LiveChatConfig extends \Magento\Framework\View\Element\Template

{

    protected $scopeConfig;

    const XML_PATH_ENABLED = 'Webguru_livechat/livechat/enabled';

    const XML_PATH_WIDGET = 'Webguru_livechat/livechat/widget';

    public function __construct(

        \Magento\Framework\App\Config\ScopeConfigInterface $scopeConfig,

        \Magento\Framework\View\Element\Template\Context $context

    )

    {

        $this->scopeConfig = $scopeConfig;

        parent::__construct($context);

    }

    public function isEnabled() {

        $storeScope = \Magento\Store\Model\ScopeInterface::SCOPE_STORE;

        return $this->scopeConfig->getValue(self::XML_PATH_ENABLED, $storeScope);

    }

    public function getWidget()

    {

        $storeScope = \Magento\Store\Model\ScopeInterface::SCOPE_STORE;

        return $this->scopeConfig->getValue(self::XML_PATH_WIDGET, $storeScope);

    }

}

Create:  your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/view/frontend/layout/default.xml

<?xml version="1.0"?>

<page xmlns:xsi="//www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="../../../../../../../lib/internal/Magento/Framework/View/Layout/etc/page_configuration.xsd">

    <body>

        <referenceContainer name="content">

            <block class="Webguru\LiveChat\Block\Adminhtml\LiveChatHelper\LiveChatConfig"

                   name="front_livechat"

                   template="Webguru_LiveChat::livechatwidget.phtml" />

        </referenceContainer>

    </body>

</page>

Create: your_magento_base/app/code/Webguru/LiveChat/view/frontend/templates/livechatwidget.phtml

<?php

if($block->isEnabled()) {

    echo $block->getWidget();

}

?>

Finally, in the terminal, type: sudo rm -rf var

And this is the outcome.

If you choose not to activate it, simply disable it in its Configuration.

Conclusion

In conclusion, integrating a live chat into M2 can significantly improve customer support and satisfaction. With our comprehensive guide on how to integrate a live chat to Magento 2, you can easily provide exceptional customer service and enhance the user experience on your online store. So, take advantage of this feature and watch your conversion rates soar. Also, check out How to Install an Extension from Magento 2 Marketplace if you need to install any other extensions.

nodes.content:
Hey there! Are you running a retail business and looking for ways to streamline your processes and enhance your customers’ experience? Integrating Magento 2 with a Point of Sale (POS) system might be the solution you’re looking for.

You may feel intimidated by the thought of integrating Magento 2 with a POS system, but trust me, it’s not as complicated as it seems. In this article, we will guide you through the entire process step-by-step, starting with selecting the appropriate POS software, setting up the integration, and handling any issues that may come up along the way.

By the end of this guide, you’ll have a clear understanding of how to integrate Magento 2 with POS systems and manage your sales and inventory effectively across both your online and offline stores. So, grab a cup of coffee, and let’s get started!

How to Integrate Magento 2 with POS Systems: Maximizing Benefits for Your Retail Business

Before you can integrate it with a Point of Sale system, you must first install Magento 2 on your server. Follow the instructions provided by your eCommerce platform and ensure the installation process is successful. You can also refer to this guide How to Install Magento 2 Enterprise Edition.

Install the POS System

If you’re looking at how to integrate Magento 2 with POS systems, you’re in luck. With the right approach, this process can be straightforward and painless. The first step is to choose a POS system that’s compatible with your eCommerce store so that you can effectively manage your sales and inventory. Once you’ve made your selection, follow the installation process carefully to ensure that everything goes smoothly without any errors. Attention to detail is key here, as it will save you headaches down the road. Whether you’re a seasoned Magento user or just starting out, successfully integrating your POS system is achievable. So, don’t fret! By following these simple steps, you can seamlessly integrate Magento 2 with your POS system and take your business to the next level.

Connect Magento 2 and the POS System

Now that you have successfully installed the Point of Sale system, it’s time to connect it to your Magento 2 store. To achieve this, you can use an API key or a similar method that enables seamless communication between the two systems, ensuring data exchange and synchronization. With this step accomplished, you’re one step closer to efficient management of your sales and inventory across both online and offline stores.

Configure the POS System

Upon successfully linking the Point of Sale (POS) system to Magento 2, the next step is to fine-tune the POS system settings to suit your unique business needs. This may involve establishing product categories, generating bespoke fields, and customizing payment options as per your preferences.

Test the Integration

To ensure that your Magento 2 POS integration runs smoothly, it is essential to perform comprehensive testing before going live. This involves testing the transfer of sales data between your eCommerce store and the POS system to verify that it is accurate and that all features are working as expected. Thorough testing helps businesses to ensure the reliability of their integrated system and ensures that they can reap the benefits of Magento 2 POS integration.

Go Live with the Integrated System

Now that the thorough testing of the POS integration is complete and confirmed to be functioning correctly, it’s time to take the next step and go live with the integrated system. The implementation of the Magento 2 POS system can offer a multitude of benefits for businesses, including streamlining processes and enhancing the customer experience. With this powerful tool in hand, businesses can optimize sales management and operations, driving growth and success to new heights. Don’t let your business fall behind in the race, take advantage of the integrated Magento 2 POS system today and stay ahead of the curve. Remember, implementing this innovative technology is just the first step towards achieving sustainable growth and success in the competitive retail industry.

Conclusion

Hey there, fellow business owners! Are you tired of the hassle that comes with managing inventory, accounting, and overall business operations? If so, integrating Magento 2 with your Point of Sale (POS) system could be the solution you’ve been looking for.

Not only does this integration provide the benefits mentioned above, but it also centralizes sales data from both online and in-store transactions. This means that you’ll be able to make more informed decisions, reduce errors, and save valuable time and resources.

Investing in the integration of Magento 2 with POS systems is a wise move for businesses looking to stay competitive in today’s retail landscape. By following the easy steps outlined in this blog on How to Integrate Magento 2 with POS Systems, you’ll be able to streamline your inventory management, simplify your accounting, and ultimately improve your bottom line.

By harnessing the power of an eCommerce platform and a POS system, you’ll be able to take your retail operations to the next level and stay ahead of the competition. Don’t wait – start reaping the benefits of improved sales management, enhanced efficiency, and a more streamlined customer experience today!

nodes.content:
May every online merchant be familiar with sending systems. In this post, we provide a general guideline on How to set up SMTP Email for Magento 2 stores. If you’re wondering about the default SMTP settings in Magento 2, it’s important to note that the platform is designed to work with a wide range of online mail servers and providers. What is the default SMTP settings in Magento 2 is a common question among users, as the configuration for the default email mode in Magento 2 can be complicated for new users. However, this guide aims to give you a deeper understanding of Magento 2 SMTP settings. SMTP, or Simple Mail Transfer Protocol, is a standard email-sending system first introduced in the late 20th century. By default, Magento 2 uses its built-in SMTP functionality to send online mail, but as mentioned earlier, this may not always be effective in ensuring that your emails reach your customers’ inboxes. Configuring SMTP Email using the how to set up SMTP email for Magento 2 guidelines is a great way to improve the deliverability of your emails and maximize the effectiveness of your online mail marketing efforts.

3 Steps Guide: How to Set Up SMTP Email for Magento 2

Step 1: Obtain a Valid Email Address

If you’re wondering about the default Simple Mail Transfer Protocol settings in Magento 2, it’s important to note that the platform is designed to work with a wide range of email servers and providers. However, the default SMTP settings may not always be effective in ensuring that your online emails reach your customers’ inboxes. This is where Magento 2 SMTP settings come into play. By configuring SMTP online mail for your Magento 2 store using the how to set up SMTP email for Magento 2 guidelines, you can improve the deliverability of your online mail and prevent them from being sent to spam or outbox folders.

To get started, you’ll need to obtain a valid online mail address for your domain by following the guidelines provided by your server administrator or email hosting provider. This step is also known as SMTP Email setting for Magento 2. Once you have a valid email address, you can proceed with configuring an SMTP email using the steps provided by the SMTP extension or other available resources. Properly setting up SMTP emails is crucial for ensuring that your emails are being delivered to your customers’ inboxes and maximizing the effectiveness of your email marketing efforts.

Step 2: Configure Email Sending for Magento Stores

To configure email sending for your Magento store, follow these steps:

1. Navigate to the Magento Admin Panel and choose Stores > Settings > Configuration.

2. On the left side of the panel, select Store Email Address under General.

3. Go to the General Contact section to make adjustments to the default settings.

4. In the Sender Name field, enter a name that you want to appear as the sender of any online mail newsletters. It is recommended to choose a name that is associated with the General Contact identity.

5. In the Sender Email field, provide the corresponding online mail address.

6. Repeat these steps for each email address that you want to use in the future.

7. Don’t forget to click the Save button to apply the online mail settings for your M2 store.

Step 3: Maintain Your Sales Email Configuration

To keep your sales online mail configuration up-to-date, follow these steps:

1. Set up the Magento sales system for your store.

2. Pay attention to the configuration of all related online mail messages to ensure that the sender’s information remains accurate.

3. In the admin panel, navigate to Sales, then select Sales online mail to access the settings edit page.

4. Under Order, check that all sender information is correct.

5. Email sending is a crucial factor in the success of any online merchant. After making the necessary adjustments, click the Save button to complete the configuration.

Conclusion

If you’re looking to learn how to set up SMTP email for Magento 2, you may be interested in using the Magento 2 SMTP extension. The default SMTP in Magento 2 is great for reaching more customers and boosting sales, but it can often send online mails to spam or outbox folders instead of customers’ inboxes. The Magento 2 SMTP extension can solve this problem and enhance the effectiveness of your email marketing efforts.

To install the SMTP extension for your e-commerce store, simply log in to your admin panel, go to the “System” section, and choose “Web Setup Wizard.” Follow the steps provided to download and install the SMTP extension. For more information and details on how this extension can benefit your store, please visit our website.

nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that offers a wide range of shipping methods to deliver products to customers. By default, customers can choose the shipping method they prefer during the checkout process for that you can also add Custom form at end. However, this can be a time-consuming task, especially for online stores with a large number of orders. To streamline this process, Magento 2 allows you to auto-select the shipping method based on specific criteria.

This blog post will guide you through the process of how to auto select shipping method in Magento 2.

Steps to Auto Select Shipping Method in Magento 2

Step 1: Create a Custom Module

The first step in auto-selecting the shipping method in Magento 2 is to create a custom module. This module will contain the logic for selecting the shipping method. To create a custom module in Magento 2, you need to create the following directories and files:

    app/code/[VendorName]/[ModuleName]/registration.php

    app/code/[VendorName]/[ModuleName]/etc/module.xml

    app/code/[VendorName]/[ModuleName]/etc/events.xml

The registration.php file is used to register the module in Magento 2. The module.xml file contains the module’s metadata, such as the module name and version. The events.xml file is used to define the events that the module listens to.

Step 2: Write an Observer

The next step is to write an observer to listen to the event of the checkout page load. This observer will be triggered when the checkout page is loaded and it will contain the logic for auto-selecting the shipping method. To write an observer, you need to create the following file:

app/code/[VendorName]/[ModuleName]/Observer/ShippingMethodObserver.php

In this file, you need to define the observer class and implement the execute method. This method will contain the logic for auto-selecting the shipping method.

Step 3: Get the Shipping Address

Once the observer is created, you need to get the shipping address information to use it for auto-selecting the shipping method. To get the shipping address, you can use the following code:

$shippingAddress = $quote->getShippingAddress();

Step 4: Set the Shipping Method

The next step is to set the shipping method based on your specific requirements. You can set the shipping method based on various criteria, such as the weight of the order, the destination country, etc. To set the shipping method, you can use the following code:

$shippingAddress->setShippingMethod($shippingMethodCode);

Step 5: Run the Code

Finally, you need to run the code and test it to see if the shipping method is auto-selected as expected. You can do this by placing an order on your online store and checking if the shipping method is automatically selected.

Conclusion

Auto-selecting the shipping method in Magento 2 can save you a significant amount of time and effort, especially if you have a large number of orders. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform that offers a multitude of customization options to build custom forms for various purposes. Whether it’s a contact form, feedback form, or any other type, Magento 2 provides the capability to create forms with ease. Custom forms are an important part of any e-commerce website as they provide a way for customers to communicate with the store owners and provide valuable feedback. A well-designed form can increase user engagement and help improve the overall customer experience.

In this guide, we will take a step-by-step approach for how to create custom form in Magento 2, starting from creating a module to updating the layout to display the form on the frontend. By following these steps, you will be able to create a custom form for your e-commerce store that meets your specific needs and enhances the customer experience.

Steps to Create Custom Form in Magento 2

Step 1: Create a module

The first step in creating a custom form in Magento 2 is to create a module. A module is a set of files that are used to extend the functionality of the platform. To create a module, you need to create a directory structure in the app/code directory. The directory structure should look like this: app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}.

Step 2: Define the module

Once you have created the directory structure, you need to define your module. You can do this by creating a module.xml file in the app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}/etc directory. In this file, you need to specify the module name, version, and dependencies.

Step 3: Create a form

Now that you have defined your module, you can start creating your form. To create a form, you need to create a form.xml file in the app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}/view/frontend/ui_component directory. In this file, you can define the form fields, their types, and the layout of the form.

Step 4: Create a controller

After you have created the form, you need to create a controller to handle the form submissions. To do this, you need to create a controller file in the app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}/Controller/Index directory. In this file, you can define the form submission logic and the processing of the form data.

Step 5: Create a template

To display the form on the frontend, you need to create a template file. You can create a template file in the app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}/view/frontend/templates directory. In this file, you can define the HTML and CSS of the form.

Step 6: Update the layout

Finally, you need to update the layout to display the form on the frontend. To do this, you need to create a layout file in the app/code/{VendorName}/{ModuleName}/view/frontend/layout directory. In this file, you can define the block, template, and URL of the form.

You may also feel helpful reading our blog post on How to Use a Custom Price Template in Magento 2. 

Conclusion

In conclusion, creating custom forms in Magento 2 is a straightforward process that can be done in a few simple steps. By following the steps outlined in this guide, you can create a custom form for your e-commerce store in no time.you may also love to read how to create configurable product in Magento 2.

nodes.content:
What is Store View in Magento 2? Magento 2 is a system that enables the creation of store views, stores, and websites, all of which can be managed through a single admin panel, providing customers with a wide variety of high-quality products. Magento 2 allows for the creation of a website with multiple stores, each with distinct designs, purposes, and product offerings. Store Views, in turn, are variations of the same store in different languages. Every Magento 2 store comes with a default store view, and additional store views can be created to provide language support for customers from different countries. This enables customers to navigate the store in their preferred language.

What is Store View in Magento 2: Understanding the Importance of Language Support in E-commerce

To create a new store view in Magento:

Go to Stores > Settings > All stores and press the “Create Store View” button.

Fill in the Store View Information:

  • Choose the Store the newly created store view will be assigned to.
  • Give the Magento store view a Name and a Code (it is important to set store codes for SEO purposes in URLs)
  • Enable or disable the store view
  • Set the Sort Order of the store view, which defines its position in the list of Magento store views.
  • Press the “Save Store View” button after entering all the information.

To set the language for each store view, go to Admin Panel > Stores > Configuration and switch to the store view you want to set the language for.

  • In the General > Locale Options section, set the Locale (language) for the store view.
  • Run the CLI command: “php bin/magento indexer: reindex” to do the Magento reindex.

What is Store View in Magento 2 is a powerful feature that enables online merchants to present their products and services to customers in multiple languages and regions. After creating new store views, a store switcher will appear on the storefront, allowing customers to choose the store view they want to navigate to. This feature is especially useful for businesses with a global customer base that requires different languages, currencies, and pricing configurations. Additionally, Magento 2 offers a Language Switcher that automatically directs customers to the store view in their local language based on geolocation or browser language. By using these features, businesses can create a more personalized shopping experience, which can help improve customer satisfaction and boost sales.

Conclusion

In conclusion, creating a new store view in Magento is a straightforward process that involves going to the “Stores > Settings > All stores” section and pressing the “Create Store View” button. The store view information, including the store it will be assigned to, name and code, and sort order, must be filled in before pressing the “Save Store View” button. Additionally, it is important to set the language for each store view by going to the “Admin Panel > Stores > Configuration” section and setting the locale (language) in the “General > Locale Options” section. Finally, to ensure that the store views are properly indexed, it is necessary to run the “php bin/magento indexer: reindex” command.

With Store View in Magento 2, store owners can create multiple views of their website, each with unique language, currency, and pricing configurations, making it easier for customers to shop and navigate the site. By leveraging this feature, merchants can create a tailored shopping experience for their customers, which can help increase sales and improve customer satisfaction. Therefore, understanding What is Store View in Magento 2 is crucial for businesses looking to expand their reach and connect with customers worldwide.

nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 offers three methods for manually installing modules: through Composer, a ZIP archive, and via the browser. The method chosen will depend on how the module was obtained. nodes.content:
Magento 2 offers three methods for manually installing modules: through Composer, a ZIP archive, and via the browser. The method chosen will depend on how the module was obtained. Modules can either be purchased from the store or obtained from third-party sources. How to Install Modules Manually in Magento 2 is a straightforward process that requires a few steps to follow and a basic understanding of Magento’s file structure and command line interface. This guide will walk you through the process of installing modules manually in Magento 2.

If you’re wondering how to install a module in Magento 2 manually, there are a few different methods to consider. If you’ve purchased a module from the Magento store, you’ll need to use the access keys generated in your marketplace account to add the module to the Magento admin panel. This will synchronize with your Magento marketplace account and allow you to manage the installation of purchased packages. On the other hand, advanced users who prefer to manually install modules in Magento 2 can do so using Composer. If you choose to install a module via Composer, you’ll need to enter the access keys if they haven’t been saved in the system.

Modules obtained from third-party sources can be in the form of an archive or a link to a repository, such as GitHub. These can also be installed via the Composer.

Each of the installation methods is explained in detail.

To generate “Access Keys” in a Magento account, you can either log in or create a new account on magento.com. Once logged in, click on the “Marketplace” link in your account. Another way is to go directly to the Magento extensions store. Then, in the “My Profile” section, look for “My Products/Access Keys” and generate the necessary keys.

How to Install Modules Manually in Magento 2: A Step-by-Step Guide

Installing modules via Composer

This method of installing modules is only recommended if you are familiar with using the server console. The composer is a file called composer.phar, which can be downloaded from getcomposer.org. It should be launched from the Magento root directory, which should contain a composer.json file with the configuration of the installed libraries.

The command to run the composer is:

php composer.phar <command>

If the composer is installed globally on the server, there is no need to download it, and you can refer to it in the following form:

composer <command>

If the module is distributed from the Magento repository, the following commands can be run:

php composer.phar require [vendor]/[package]

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This will handle the rest of the installation process.

If the module is from a third-party repository, it will need to be specified in the composer.json file, specifically in the “require” section.

{

   . . . . .

   "require": {

        . . . . .

   "vendor/package": "version"

 },

 .....

}

If the module is obtained from a third-party repository such as GitHub, it will need to be specified in the “repositories” section of the composer.json file.

{

   . . . . .

   "repositories": {

        . . . . .

        {

           "type": "git",

           "url": "https://github.com/ . . . . ."

       }

   },

 .....

}

The necessary information for specifying a third-party repository is usually provided with the module. After adding this information to the composer.json file, save the changes and run the following commands:

php composer.phar update [vendor]/[package]

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This will update and install the specified package.

As an example, let’s consider the installation of one of our free modules from a GitHub repository. Since the module is not from the Magento repository, it will need to be added to the composer.json file before it can be installed.

{

   . . .

   "repositories": [

       . . .

       {

           "type": "vcs",

           "url": "https://github.com/belvg-public/Magento2_ApplyTo"

       }

   ],

   . . .

}

And apply our module there:

{

   . . .

   "require": {

       . . .

       "belvg/module-applyto": "dev-master"

   }

}

After making changes to the composer.json file, the final step is to run the update command to download the necessary modules and add-ons.

php composer.phar update

Then, run the following command to install the new modules in Magento:

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

This will complete the installation process.

Installing modules via ZIP-archive :

When adding an extension to Magento 2, the first step is to copy the code to the appropriate directory. This involves extracting the contents of the zip file containing the module and copying the contents of the “Install” folder to the “app/code/” directory in the Magento 2 codebase. Once the code is in place, there are two different methods that can be used to activate the module in the store. The first method involves using the Web Setup Wizard and Component Manager, which can be accessed through the “System” menu in the admin panel. The second method is to manually run commands in the console. Both methods require the Cron tasks to be set up and running. It’s important to check for compatibility issues and dependencies and to set the proper permissions for files and folders to ensure a successful installation.

Installing modules via a browser

If you’re looking for guidance on how to install modules manually in Magento 2, there are a few steps you’ll need to follow. The first step is to copy the code to the required directory. To do this, take the zip file of the module and copy the contents of the “Install” folder to the “app/code/” directory in the Magento 2 codebase. Once the code is in the correct location, there are two methods to initialize the module in a store: using the Web Setup Wizard and Component Manager, or by manually running commands in the console. Both methods require the Cron tasks to be set up and running. To use the Web Setup Wizard, navigate to the “System” menu in the admin panel and select “Web Setup Wizard,” then “Component Manager.” From there, you’ll be able to enable all available modules. Before enabling the custom module, Magento will prompt you to create a backup. If you’re not comfortable using the Web Setup Wizard, you can also manually run commands in the console to initialize the module.

Browse through the list of available components and locate the Magento 2 extension that you wish to install. Once you find it, click on the “Install” button.

If required, create a backup before proceeding. Then, click on “Next” and finally, enable the feature by clicking on the “Enable” button.

And finally, we will see the following screen:

The module has been enabled. We can now return to the module list and enable the next one. In Magento, console commands can be executed using the command: “php bin/magento <command>”. Magento CLI offers a variety of useful console commands for managing the store, and a list of these commands can be obtained by running “php bin/magento.

But now we need to use only one:

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

The command “php bin/magento setup:upgrade” checks all modules and initiates the installation or updating process as needed. This allows you to perform both updating and installation of all modules with a single command. Additionally, for increased security or other reasons, the server can be configured to have module installations performed by a specific user.

In this case, when executing console commands:

php composer.phar <command>

php bin/magento <command>

If there are reports of insufficient rights, you can try running the commands as another user or as an administrator. For example:

“sudo -u <username> php bin/magento <command>” or “sudo php bin/magento <command>”.

Additionally, some folders may require full permission. When installing modules, for example, you may not have access to some files in the “app/etc” directory. In this case, you can use the command 

chmod 777 app/etc 

and 

chmod 644 app/etc/*.xml

to give the necessary permissions. Similarly, the “var” folder which contains many temporary files, may require permissions to be distributed to all subdirectories, to do this you can use the command 

chmod -R 777 var/

Other potential errors when installing a module through Composer include a mismatch of PHP versions and missing dependencies on other libraries. To resolve these issues, you can edit the Composer.json file to correctly set the versions. The file can be found within the module and you may need to adjust the version of the library to be loaded or make other changes. However, you can also choose to ignore these settings by using the command 

composer update [vendor]/[package] —ignore-platform-reqs

conclusion

In conclusion, installing modules and sample data in Magento 2 can be done manually through a few different methods, including adding the module code to the required directory, using the Magento Web Setup Wizard, or using console commands. When it comes to installing modules manually in Magento 2, it’s important to check for compatibility issues and dependencies and set the proper permissions for files and folders. If you’re not sure how to install modules manually in Magento 2, there are many tutorials and guides available online to help you get started. In addition to module installation, you may also be interested in learning how to install Grunt in Magento 2. This is a process that allows you to use Grunt, a JavaScript task runner, within your Magento 2 project. Grunt can help automate tasks such as compiling CSS and JavaScript, minimizing code, and more. To install Grunt in Magento 2, you’ll need to have Node.js and Grunt installed on your system. Then, you can use the command line to navigate to your Magento 2 root directory and run the command “npm install” to install the necessary dependencies. Once installed, you can use Grunt commands to automate various tasks in your project.
